title-group.article-title: Identifying and characterizing suicide decedent subtypes using deep embedded clustering

abstract.p: Subtypes of suicide decedents have not been studied at a population level using linked clinical and public health surveillance records. Identifying suicide subtypes can help facilitate the development and deployment of population-level prevention strategies. This retrospective study uses the Maryland Suicide Data Warehouse (MSDW). The analyses included 848 individuals who died by suicide as well as 4,161 individuals who died by accident in the state of Maryland between January 1st, 2016, and December 31st, 2019. These individuals had electronic health records from Johns Hopkins Medical Institutes and statewide hospital discharge data. We employed deep embedded clustering and evaluated its performance against traditional clustering approaches. We evaluated different numbers of clusters (k = 2 to 10) and assessed clustering performance using stability metrics, achieving a cross-validated prediction strength of 0.94. We then performed cluster characterization and assessed cluster stability up to 1 year before suicide death. We identified four distinct suicide profiles. Profile 1 (23.2% of suicide cases) included older individuals with high comorbid conditions. Profile 2 (19.2%) was characterized by psychiatric illness, the highest healthcare utilization, and significant social needs. Profile 3 (25.4%) consisted of younger individuals with psychiatric illness, no recorded social needs, and the highest percentage of Medicaid patients. Profile 4 (32.2%) included less clinically engaged individuals with the fewest healthcare visits. Our findings show the effective use of clustering methods to identify meaningful and stable suicide decedent profiles, revealing significant demographic and clinical differences. The identified subtypes can inform population-level suicide prevention strategies.

sec.title: Supplementary Information
sec.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1038/s41598-025-07007-4.

funding-source.institution: US National Institute of Mental Health

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The U.S. suicide rate increased by approximately 36.5% between 2000 and 2022, rising from 10.4 to 14.2 deaths per 100,000 individuals1. Provisional data indicate that in 2023, the suicide rate remained at historically high levels2. Despite the increasing suicide rate, most population-level prevention strategies are not personalized for the underlying heterogeneity of suicide and do not reach the majority of people before they die by suicide3. Improving our understanding of suicide subtypes is crucial for developing prevention strategies that have better reach and impact. However, suicide subtyping remains challenging as suicide is a multi-determined and a relatively low-frequency event from a statistical standpoint4,5.

Prior research has primarily examined theoretical subtypes of suicidal behaviors, focusing on ideation and attempts rather than death by suicide6–8. These theoretical frameworks include the stress-responsive/non-stress-responsive dichotomy based on thought patterns following stressful events9, and a four-subtype model based on clinical observations that differentiates between psychosis-linked, mood disorder-related, psychosocial, and emotional coping-based presentations. While these frameworks provide insights into suicidal behavior pathways, they rely on theoretical constructs rather than empirical validation and may not capture the complexity of suicide deaths observable in public health and health system data6,8.

While many studies have used data-driven approaches to subtype individuals at risk for suicide10–14, fewer have focused specifically on decedents. This is in part due to the difficulty of collecting detailed information on suicide decedents and the relative infrequency of states linking population-based data from several sources and systems15. Recent work using the National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS) and the Department of Defense Suicide Event Report (DoDSER) has begun to address this gap by applying latent class analysis (LCA) to identify suicide death profiles in specific populations16–18. For example, five suicide subtypes were identified in the general population using NVDRS data, based on crisis circumstances, substance use, mental health, and physical health factors16. Other studies have extended this approach to subpopulations, such as terminally ill individuals and active-duty military personnel, revealing distinct clusters driven by firearm use, relationship stressors, administrative issues, and mental illness17,18.

These studies highlight the potential of data-driven methods to identify meaningful subtypes of suicide decedents. Nonetheless, they remain constrained by the types of variables available in surveillance systems. Clinical information captured in electronic health records (EHRs), including diagnostic histories, healthcare utilization, and social needs, can offer deeper insight into the medical and behavioral pathways leading to suicide death.

Traditional unsupervised learning methods, such as k-means or LCA, have been widely used to identify data-driven subtypes of suicidal behaviors10–14,16–18. These approaches struggle to handle high-dimensional and complex data, such as EHR data. Advanced techniques, like deep embedded clustering (DEC), provide a more suitable and robust solution for subtyping suicide by effectively analyzing such complex data sources19. In fact, DEC-based methods have shown promising results in identifying high-risk clusters within diverse, high-dimensional healthcare data, including patients with heart failure and those in critical care settings20–22.

The objective of this work is to identify and characterize data-driven suicide subtypes using linked health records from a statewide data warehouse of suicide decedents in Maryland. We developed an unsupervised machine learning pipeline based on DEC, to derive stable suicide death subtypes that remained consistent across different analyses. We retrospectively evaluated the stability of these subtypes over time and examined how they differ from accidental deaths. Lastly, we assessed causes of death and analyzed differences between subtypes in the methods used to die by suicide. The characteristics and healthcare utilization patterns of the suicide subtypes identified in this study have implications for suicide prevention approaches and the management of individuals with suicidal behavior. With larger, more diverse datasets, advanced unsupervised machine learning approaches could help improve the prediction and prevention of suicide.

sec.title: Study setting and population
sec.p: This retrospective study utilized the Maryland Statewide Suicide Data Warehouse (MSDW)23, which contains health records of suicide decedents according to the Maryland Office of the Medical Examiner (OCME). The study population comprised 848 individuals who died by suicide between January 1, 2016, and December 31, 2019, with linked EHR data from Johns Hopkins Medical Institutes (JHMI) and statewide hospital discharge data from Maryland’s Health Services Cost Review Commission, available in MSDW. For comparative analysis, the study also included 4,161 accidental deaths (as determined by the medical examiner) during the same period, with similar data availability. All included decedents had at least one hospital admission in the statewide discharge data and at least one encounter in the JHMI EHR system during the study period. This reflects the complete decedent population meeting our inclusion criteria.

This study was reviewed and approved by the Johns Hopkins University’s Bloomberg School of Public Health Institutional Review Board. Due its retrospective nature, the IRB waived the need of obtaining informed consent. All health records were fully deidentified to protect patient privacy. All methods were performed in accordance with the relevant guidelines and regulations.

sec.title: Data and variables selection
sec.p: The dataset consisted of demographic, diagnosis, procedure, and encounter/utilization data. Demographic features used in the analysis included age at the time of death and marital status. Healthcare utilization features included the last recorded payer type (i.e., Medicare, Medicaid, private, and self-pay), and counts of outpatient, inpatient, and emergency department (ED) visits, which represented patterns in healthcare access and usage.

Diagnosis variables in MSDW were grouped into multiple risk indicator domains using a combination of validated coding systems24. Clinical conditions, including chronic diseases and psychiatric disorders, were included in the analysis as binary variables. Charlson comorbidity index (CCI) was used to provide context on past health events and overall disease burden25. The diagnostic labels and procedures were grouped using the Clinical Classifications Software Refined (CCSR)24. We included variables for depression, suicidal ideation and attempts, anxiety, bipolar, neurodevelopmental, and psychotic disorders. Procedure variables included psychiatric evaluation, counseling/psychotherapy, and emergency evaluations. We also included substance use disorders and social determinants of health (SDOH). The SDOH variables encompassed healthcare access, housing stability, social support, and psychosocial stressors, coded using ICD-10-CM codes from the Social Interventions Research and Evaluation Network (SIREN) compendium26. In addition, we included health and wellness factors derived from ICD-10-CM behavioral health markers, which capture lifestyle-related risks such as emotional wellness, nutrition, physical activity, and sleep quality27.

Only variables with at least 5% prevalence in the cohort were retained for clustering, resulting in 81 out of 129 variables. To ensure that clusters captured clinical and behavioral patterns rather than demographic groupings, we excluded sex, race, and ethnicity from the clustering process. These demographic variables were later used to characterize the resulting clusters.

Data from OCME, including the means of suicide, geographic location, and narrative descriptions, were not included in clustering but were later used for cluster characterization and interpretation. This approach ensured that the identified profiles reflected risk factors observable during life rather than postmortem circumstances.

sec.title: Clustering approach
sec.p: We explored different learning approaches to address the high dimensionality of MSDW data (Fig. 1). A common approach in machine learning involves first applying dimensionality reduction techniques, followed by clustering algorithms. This two-step process simplifies the data structure, making clustering more effective28. Using DEC, we integrated these two steps into a single process, simultaneously learning a low-dimensional representation of the data while optimizing cluster assignments29. This leads to grouping similar patients closer together in the latent space. This approach is particularly effective in uncovering complex patterns in healthcare data, yielding more accurate and meaningful clusters21,22.

The DEC model combines a multilayer perceptron autoencoder with a custom clustering layer based on k-means. An autoencoder is a special type of neural network that is trained to encode its input to its output. The DEC model we developed for this study was configured with 5 hidden layers of 256 nodes each and a bottleneck layer of 24 latent features. The model is pre-trained to initialize the weights, followed by further training to fine-tune the embeddings. Initial cluster assignments were generated using k-means, followed by a refinement process that computed probabilistic assignments of patients to clusters. This iterative process optimized both the data representation and cluster assignments to identify the most natural groupings in the data.

sec.title: Evaluation and optimal number of clusters
sec.p: Determining the optimal number of clusters is a crucial step in unsupervised learning. Without ground truth labels, this task typically relies on either expert review or statistical heuristics such as the elbow method, gap statistic, or average silhouette score30. While these methods assess internal validity, they don’t guarantee that clusters will be reproducible in new data. For many clinical applications, cluster validation often involves examining future outcomes to establish risk levels for each group. However, since our outcome of interest (suicide death) is terminal, we cannot use this approach. Instead, we prioritized cluster stability, focusing on how consistently the clusters could be reproduced across different subsets of our data.

We used prediction strength (PS) to evaluate the stability and reproducibility of the clustering results. PS is a cross-validation-based method that quantifies how consistently cluster assignments hold across different subsets of the data. The procedure works as follows: the dataset is split into training and testing sets. A clustering algorithm is applied independently to each set, generating two sets of cluster assignments. For each cluster in the training set, the algorithm examines how well the corresponding cluster structure is preserved in the test set by comparing pairwise co-membership (i.e., whether pairs of patients that were clustered together in training remain clustered together in testing). The PS score ranges from 0 to 1, where higher values indicate greater consistency in cluster membership across splits.

To determine the optimal number of clusters (k), we computed the average PS across 5-fold cross-validation iterations. The largest value of k for which the average PS exceeds a predefined threshold, typically 0.8 as recommended by Tibshirani and Walther31, is considered the most stable and reliable solution.

We considered cluster numbers k in the range of 2 to 10. We used a stratified k-fold cross-validation with 5 splits and evaluated the stability of the clusters on the holdout folds. Stratification was conducted on age, sex, and race to maintain the proportions of each class within the folds, ensuring that each fold is representative of the overall dataset. During each fold, the data was split into training and test sets, the clustering model was trained on the training set, and performance metrics were computed on the test set. This process was repeated for each clustering method and cluster size. The maximum k across methods with a cross-validated PS above the 0.8 threshold was used to select the best approach. We also computed internal validity measures such as the silhouette, Calinski-Harabasz, and Davies-Bouldin scores32–34.

sec.title: Statistical analysis and clusters characterization
sec.p: We assessed differences between clusters using chi-square tests for categorical variables and Kruskal-Wallis H-tests for continuous variables when normality assumptions weren’t met. For normally distributed continuous variables, we used one-way ANOVA. All p-values were adjusted for multiple comparisons using the Bonferroni correction. Where significant differences were found, post hoc Dunn tests were performed to identify specific between-cluster differences. Statistical significance was set at p < 0.05 after correction.

To evaluate how distinct each cluster is from the overall data distribution, we computed the standardized mean difference (SMD) from the overall mean for all covariates. We then trained a multiclass XGBoost classifier with cluster membership as the target variable and used SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) analysis to identify the top predictive features for each cluster. XGBoost is a scalable, tree-based gradient boosting algorithm known for its speed and performance in classification tasks​35. SHAP analysis assigns each feature an importance value for a particular prediction, offering interpretable explanations for model outputs36. Additionally, we censored the data at different time points before the date of death (i.e., 12, 6, 3, and 1 months) and reran our clustering pipeline to check if we could retrospectively recover the same clusters.

We examined differences in the means of suicide across clusters. Means were categorized from medical examiner text narratives using regular expressions and a hierarchical classification based on lethality: (1) firearm, (2) hanging/hypoxia, (3) overdose, and (4) other methods. In cases with multiple documented methods, we assigned the method with highest lethality. This classification hierarchy was validated by a clinical psychiatrist and aligns with research on method lethality37,38.

Finally, to further validate that the identified patterns were unique to suicide deaths rather than reflecting general healthcare utilization patterns, we conducted a comparative analysis. We applied the same DEC methodology to a cohort of 4,161 accidental deaths (as determined by the medical examiner) that occurred during the same period. We visualized the suicide and accidental death clusters using Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection (UMAP)39. However, since the DEC models were trained separately for each group, the UMAP projections do not provide a direct measure of profile similarity or dissimilarity. To quantitatively assess differences, we calculated pairwise Gower distances between cluster centroids based on the original input features40. Gower distances provide a normalized measure of dissimilarity, ranging from 0 (identical) to 1 (maximally different), and serve as the metric for the suicide and accident profiles comparison.

sec.title: Population characteristics
sec.p: The average age of suicide decedents was 49.3 years (SD = 19.4). 72.1% of patients were male, 75.5% were White, 14.5% were Black, and 32.4% were married (Table 1).

Over half of the decedents (56.1%) had at least one psychiatric diagnosis, with 39.6% diagnosed with depression, 37.4% with anxiety, 29.1% with documented suicidal ideation or attempt. 68.8% had one or more ED evaluation, and 34.9% had a history of substance use. Close to a quarter of the decedents (23.2%) were found to have at least one documented social need. More specifically, 10.7% experienced employment issues, 6.7% dealt with social isolation, 5.4% faced housing issues, and 5.3% were under stressful conditions.

Additionally, decedents presented with various comorbidities, including chronic pain or neuropathy (21.1%), essential hypertension (35.6%), renal disease (14.7%), obesity (13.9%), pulmonary disease (12.7%), and thyroid disorder (11.8%). The mean CCI was 1.0 (SD = 1.5), indicating a mild overall burden of comorbid conditions. When categorized, 53.1% had no documented comorbidity (CCI = 0), 34.1% had mild comorbidity (CCI scores of 1–2), and 12.8% had moderate to severe comorbidity (CCI scores of 3 or higher).

For comparison, we analyzed 4,616 accidental death cases during the same period (Supplementary Table S1). This population was notably older, with a mean age of 64.5 years (SD = 22.4) and 52.4% aged 65 or older. The gender distribution differed from suicide decedents, with 42.2% being female. The racial composition was similar, with 67.2% White and 24.0% Black. A lower proportion were married (28.9%) compared to suicide decedents. The accidental death group showed a higher burden of medical comorbidity and lower severe mental health conditions such as psychotic illness (7.3% vs. 9.3%), and documented suicidal ideation or prior self-harm (11.9% vs. 29.1%). Social determinants such as housing instability and employment issues were also less prominent in this group and Medicare was the predominant insurance type (40.0%), reflecting the older age distribution.

sec.title: Clustering performance
sec.p: Multiple approaches were tested for the clustering process. The best learning approach was DEC, which consistently outperformed other approaches in prediction strength (Fig. 2) and internal validity metrics (Supplementary Figures S1, S2, S3). The maximum cluster number above the 0.8 threshold was 4, with a cross-validated PS score of 0.94 (SD = 0.029). This indicates that, on average, 94% of cluster assignments were recovered across different validation folds. At k = 4, DEC also demonstrated tighter separation with a higher Calinski-Harabasz index of 215.75 (SD = 35.79), a higher silhouette score of 0.49 (SD = 0.031), and a lower Davies-Bouldin index at 0.72 (SD = 0.05). After establishing DEC as the best approach, we applied it to the full dataset.

The clustering separation is further demonstrated through the UMAP visualization technique (Supplemental Figure S4). Two UMAP 3D plots were rendered, one using the original features and the other using the embeddings learned by the DEC model. The plots demonstrate the effectiveness of the DEC method in learning embeddings that can uncover distinct suicide profiles present in the dataset.

After identifying the four clusters, we evaluated separation between them across multiple domains using standardized mean differences from the overall mean (Fig. 3). Feature importance analysis through SHAP values confirmed these patterns, identifying similar key differentiating characteristics (Supplementary Figures S5 and S6), further reinforcing these findings.

The temporal stability of these clusters was assessed using a Sankey diagram (Fig. 4). Overall, the majority of decedents remained in the same patient profiles up to 6 months before the time of death (Macro Precision = 0.74; Macro Recall = 0.72; Adjusted rand index = 0.38; Purity = 0.72) (Table S3). However, as additional data becomes available closer to the time of death, decedents tend to transition between clusters, particularly from profile 4 (lower utilization) to other profiles.

sec.title: Suicide decedents profiles
sec.p: Four distinct suicide death profiles were identified (Table 2; Fig. 3, Supplementary Table S2), with significant differences across domains such as demographics, comorbidities, psychiatric conditions, healthcare utilization, and social needs (adjusted p < 0.001). Feature importance analysis further highlighted the top 10 covariates contributing to cluster differentiation, both overall and for each individual profile (Supplementary Figures S5 and S6). Overall, the combination of social determinants of health, mental health conditions, substance use issues, and healthcare utilization patterns were the most influential variables in predicting these profiles.

sec.title: Profile 1: Medical highest acuity
sec.p: This profile comprised 23.2% (n = 197) of the sample and was characterized by a high prevalence of comorbidities and health conditions (Table 2). Most decedents in this cluster were aged 65 or older (51.8%) with a mean age of 62.2 years (SD = 18.0). A notable proportion of individuals in this group were married (43.1%) and predominantly White (86.8%). Overall health utilization was high, mainly driven by outpatient visits, with 90.4% falling into the highest quartile of healthcare encounters. Individuals in this profile also had the highest rates of chronic conditions, including essential hypertension (64.0%), pulmonary disease (30.5%), renal disease (28.9%), chronic pain or neuropathy (35.0%), myocardial infarction (31.0%), and cancer (23.9%). CCI was significantly high in this group, with 36% having moderate to high levels of comorbidities. Additionally, this profile had the highest proportion of self-pay individuals (46.2%), indicating potential for financial distress. Mental health services were less prominent, with lower rates of substance use disorders compared to other profiles.

sec.title: Profile 2: Psychiatric illness with social needs
sec.p: This profile represents 19.2% (n = 163) of suicide decedents. Individuals in this profile faced significant mental health problems, substance use, and social needs (Table 2). They had a mean age of 44.2 years (SD = 16.6), were predominantly aged 25–44 (42.9%), and had a higher proportion of females (36.8%) compared to other profiles. In terms of insurance coverage, 22.1% were Medicaid beneficiaries and 23.3% had Medicare. This profile had the highest rates of psychiatric illnesses (98.2%) and substance use (74.2%), particularly opiates (26.4%) and cannabis (30.1%). A significant number (80.4%) experienced depressive disorders, 73.6% had suicidal ideation or previous attempts, and 23.9% had psychotic illness.

Additionally, 100% of individuals in this group faced some types of social needs, and 79.8% had a record for a social admission, which refers to a hospital or healthcare admission due to social factors such as lack of housing, food insecurity, or the need for social support services. This profile had the highest prevalence of stressful conditions (23.9%), social isolation (33.1%), and housing issues (27.0%). Health utilization was high, with 73.6% in the highest quartile for encounters involving elevated inpatient and ED visits. Certain chronic conditions were also more prevalent in this group compared to other profiles, including chronic pain or neuropathy (38.0%), asthma (18.4%), and hepatitis (14.1%).

sec.title: Profile 3: Psychiatric illness with no recorded social needs
sec.p: Accounting for 25.4% (n = 215) of the sample, this profile featured significant psychiatric conditions without documented social needs (Table 2). This profile had the lowest mean age at 41.6 years (SD = 17.3) and the highest percentage of individuals aged 24 or younger (19.1%). Although still predominantly White (67.9%), this group had the highest rate of minorities among all profiles, with 18.6% Black and 13.5% Other (i.e., not White or Black). A substantial percentage of decedents in this group (56.3%) were never married, single, or of unknown marital status. Profile 3 had the highest percentage of Medicaid patients (27.4%) and 26.0% were covered by Medicare, meaning over half (53.4%) were covered by public insurance programs. Healthcare utilization was moderate, with 49.3% in the third quartile for healthcare encounters. Psychiatric illnesses were present in 87.4% of individuals, with high rates of depression (58.1%), anxiety (53.5%), psychotic illness (11.2%), and suicidal ideation or previous attempt (45.1%). Substance use was also high (73.5%), with cannabis use at 15.8% and opiate use at 16.7%.

sec.title: Profile 4: Lower utilization
sec.p: This profile is the largest group, representing 32.2% (n = 273) of suicide decedents. This profile is characterized by the lowest level of clinical engagement and fewer documented health conditions (Table 2). This group had the highest proportion of individuals aged 45–64 (38.5%), 75.5% were White, and 36.3% were married (second highest after profile 1). 20.1% of individuals in this profile resided in non-urban areas, which was the second highest percentage of rural residents after Profile 1 (28.9%). Health utilization was notably low, with 50.5% in the lowest quartile for healthcare encounters, showing the fewest outpatient, inpatient, and ED visits among all profiles. This profile also had the lowest rates of most chronic conditions and psychiatric illnesses (4.4%), including depression (1.1%) and anxiety (1.1%), and minimal engagement with mental health services. 19.4% of individuals had self-pay as the last recorded payer type, which likely reflects those facing barriers to access care.

sec.title: Healthcare utilization by suicide profiles
sec.p: Overall healthcare utilization showed significant differences across profiles. Profiles 1 and 2 had high utilization across healthcare settings, with the highest median total encounters (both 23.0, IQR = [14.0, 40.0] and [10.0, 54.0] respectively), significantly higher than profiles 3 (median = 8.0, IQR = [3.0, 20.0]) and 4 (median = 1.0, IQR = [0.0, 4.0]). Profile 1’s utilization was driven by outpatient visits, while profile 2 showed higher inpatient and ED use.

Outpatient visits varied significantly among profiles. Profile 1 had the highest median outpatient visits (20.0, IQR = [11.0, 33.0]), significantly different from profiles 2, 3, and 4 (Post-hoc Dunn tests, p < 0.001). Profile 2 had a median of 14.0 visits (IQR = [5.0, 42.0]), while profiles 3 and 4 had medians of 6.0 (IQR = [2.0, 15.0]) and 1.0 (IQR = [0.0, 3.0]) respectively.

For inpatient care, profile 2 had significantly higher psychiatric admissions (mean = 0.834, max = 7.0) than profiles 3 and 4 (Post-hoc Dunn tests, p < 0.001 and p = 0.003). ED utilization was highest in profile 2 (Post-hoc Dunn tests, p < 0.001), with 91.4% having at least one ED visit. Most individuals in profiles 1 and 3 also had ED visits, with profile 2 showing the highest rate of ED evaluations (91.4%).

sec.title: Methods of suicide across profiles
sec.p: Profiles showed differences in methods of death (Table 3). Overall, suicide by firearm was the most common method (37.7%). Statistically significant differences were observed in causes of death across the profiles for firearm death, hanging or hypoxia, and overdose, but not for other methods. Firearm deaths were most prevalent in Profile 1 (52.3%) and Profile 4 (46.1%), both of which had a higher proportion of non-urban residents. Profiles 2 and 3, with lower non-urban representation, had fewer firearm-related deaths (20.9% and 26.5%, respectively). Hanging or hypoxia were most common in profiles related to psychiatric illness and substance use with the highest levels in profile 2 (41.1%) and profile 3 (37.7%), while profile 1 had the lowest level (15.7%). Similarly, overdose suicides were more frequent in profile 2 (28.8%) and profile 3 (26.5%) compared to profile 1 (23.9%) and profile 4 (14.8%).

sec.title: Validating profiles against accidental deaths
sec.p: We applied the DEC clustering methodology to 4,161 accidental deaths that occurred during the same period. The UMAP visualization (Fig. 5A) of both suicide and accidental death clusters demonstrates the effectiveness of DEC in learning embeddings that can uncover distinct profiles within each death type.

To quantitatively assess differences between suicide and accidental death profiles, we calculated pairwise Gower distances between cluster centroids using the original input features (Fig. 5B). Suicide profile 1 showed the closest similarity to an accidental death cluster (Gower distance = 0.27), but still maintained substantial differences across key features, including age, CCI, prevalence of psychiatric illness, and healthcare utilization patterns (Figure S7). The remaining suicide profiles exhibited greater differentiation, with Gower distances exceeding 0.3.

Further comparisons between suicide and accident profiles using SMDs across clinical, demographic, and social variables confirmed the differences between suicide and accident profiles (Figure S7). For instance, suicide profile 2 demonstrated substantially higher rates of documented social needs relative to accident deaths, with SMDs exceeding 3 when compared to accident profiles 1–3, and exceeding 1 when compared to accident profile 4. Suicide profile 4 exhibited lower healthcare utilization across outpatient visits, inpatient admissions, and emergency department visits compared to all accident death profiles, highlighting the minimal clinical engagement characterizing this profile.

Together, these findings validate that the identified suicide profiles capture clinical and social characteristics unique to suicide deaths, rather than reflecting general healthcare utilization patterns.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Identifying novel suicide death subtypes/profiles at the state level can help the various service sectors, public health officials, policymakers and hospital-based clinicians to devise and deploy a more evidence-informed prevention approach and assist analysts to improve predictions on a population level. However, given the relative rarity of suicide deaths, in contrast to suicidal behaviors such as ideation and attempt, applying traditional machine learning approaches to construct such profiles has remained a challenging task. To address this gap, we used the DEC methodology to identify stable and robust profiles among suicide decedents captured in MSDW. At k = 4, the DEC methodology resulted in a cross-validated prediction strength of 0.94 (SD = 0.029), which means that most cluster assignments were recovered across different validation folds. DEC also outperformed the other clustering methodologies in internal validity metrics. This underscores the efficacy and the potential of the DEC approach in identifying and characterizing patient subgroups compared to other methodologies22,29.

Our analysis revealed four meaningful suicide decedent profiles with significant differences in demographic, clinical, behavioral, and social need characteristics. These variations highlight the complexity and diversity of suicide decedents. While individuals in profiles 1, 2, and 3 demonstrated frequent healthcare service utilization, profile 4, the largest group, included individuals with minimal clinical engagement and the fewest healthcare visits. This finding emphasizes that states should not rely exclusively on hospital-based clinicians for suicide prevention as the majority of suicidal people will not seek out or confide in clinicians about their suicidal thoughts41. This reluctance can stem from many personal and structural barriers, including ambivalence about suicide, lack of perceived need for services, preference for self-management, fear of hospitalization, and barriers related to stigma, time, costs, and access42,43. Additionally, research shows that many clinicians do not feel comfortable asking about or addressing suicide risk44. For effective population-level suicide prevention, efforts must extend beyond health providers in hospital and community-based settings to include public health workforce efforts in other service sectors such as schools, the justice system, child welfare, and workplaces. All these sectors must be equipped to identify and manage people at risk for suicide if we hope to reduce suicide rates at the population level.

Profile 1 included older individuals with high comorbidity burdens and financial stress indicated by the high percentage of self-pay bills. Physical illness can lead to chronic pain which has an effect on a person’s life, especially when it leads to a disruption of daily activities, thereby significantly increasing the risk for suicide45. Increased access to palliative care and chronic pain management, as well as depression screening in primary care, may benefit this subgroup46. Feelings of distress and helplessness may not be prioritized by patients who are dealing with physical illness47. The mental health burden in chronic pain patients, coupled with perceived stress can be an avenue for assessment and preventative intervention before risk escalates48. Additionally, since the high utilization in this group is mainly driven by outpatient visits along with emergency department visits, it is important to organize care for these patients through interdisciplinary care teams that can ensure transitions between care settings and confirm that mental health is not overlooked. Finally, profile 1 had high rates of non-urban residency and predominantly used firearms for suicide consistent with studies suggesting that rural areas have higher rates of firearm ownership and less access to mental health services, contributing to elevated suicide rates49. This highlights the need to screen this group for firearm access, encourage safe storage, and utilize extreme risk protection orders to restrict access for individuals in crisis50.

Patients in both profiles 2 and 3 had the highest proportions of Medicaid enrollees (profile 2: 22.1%; profile 3: 27.4%) with co-occurring mental illnesses and substance use, yet the two profiles differed in several key aspects. Profile 2 exhibited significant social needs and substantial healthcare utilization, highlighting the intersection of psychiatric disorders and social needs. Individuals in profile 2 demonstrated higher ED utilization (median 3.0 visits) compared to profile 3 (median 1.0 visit), despite also having higher outpatient visit rates (median 14.0 visits versus 6.0 in profile 3). This suggests that the presence of social needs may drive increased emergency service utilization even among individuals with frequent outpatient visits. Social disruptions such as financial insecurity, employment issues, legal problems, are well-known precipitating events to suicidal behavior51,52. The higher ED use observed in profile 2 also aligns with known associations between social needs and emergency care utilization. Prior research shows patients with unmet social needs have 60% higher ED utilization rates compared to those without such needs53. Given the combination of elevated ED use, social admissions, and psychiatric burden, there should be efforts to expand access to outpatient mental health care options to this group. Ensuring continuity of care through case management and coordination with social services is essential to address the complex needs of patients in this profile. This is also a population that may benefit from assertive community treatment (ACT) and housing-first models, which have been shown to reduce suicide risk among socially disadvantaged individuals54,55.

In contrast, individuals in profile 3 had a much lower recording of social challenges. Profile 3 primarily consisted of younger individuals facing the dual challenges of mental illness and substance use disorders but with minimal documentation of social needs. Suicide by overdose was highest in profiles 2 and 3, highlighting the need for programs such as integrated behavioral health care, which combine mental health and substance abuse treatment56. School-based programs focused on increasing mental health education in middle and high school students while reducing stigma and increasing skills can also be beneficial in reaching younger individuals in profile 3 before their conditions escalate57,58.

Profile 4 consisted of individuals with the lowest utilization and the fewest recorded health conditions. This profile had the second largest proportion of non-urban residents and relatively high firearm-related suicides, suggesting that limited healthcare engagement and increased access to firearms in rural areas may contribute to higher firearm suicide rates. Additionally, this profile had the highest proportion of decedents aged 45–64, a group often at increased risk of undiagnosed or untreated chronic health issues and psychosocial stressors, which may exacerbate mental health risks. This subtype likely represents a combination of individuals who are less clinically engaged, those with barriers to healthcare access, and patients who belong to one of the previous 3 profiles but have data gaps because they received care outside the data providers of MSDW. This group presents a significant challenge for clinical intervention due to limited healthcare engagement, reducing opportunities for screening, referral, and targeted care. Instead, addressing their needs may require a broader public health and policy approach, including firearm restriction policies59,60, responsible media reporting guidelines61, and universal mental health education initiatives62. Understanding and addressing the reasons for low healthcare utilization in this group is also essential to develop suicide prevention strategies tailored to their unique needs. For instance, active outreach could help identify barriers, promote engagement, and encourage these individuals to seek care when needed. However, such approaches must carefully navigate privacy and ethical considerations. Additionally, ongoing efforts to integrate insurance claims data and other sources of data into MSDW will help further elucidate this profile’s composition.

The findings of this study provide empirical information on suicide subtypes, which can inform conceptual models for suicide and highlight the diversity of decedents. Additionally, our profiles 1, 2, and 3 show notable similarities to typologies proposed by Xiao et al.18, mapping closely to three out of their five identified classes. Specifically, profile 1 aligns with the “physical health problems” subtype. Both profiles 2 and 3 share characteristics with the “comorbid mental health and substance use disorders” subtype. Given that substance use is less prevalent in profile 3 compared to profile 2, this profile can also be conceptualized as similar to the “mental disorders alone” subtype. Profile 4, characterized by low healthcare utilization, does not have a direct analog in previous work. However, it is important to note that the data types and variables differ across studies and specific subtypes may emerge due to these differences. Nonetheless, the observed convergence between our health records-based profiles and those identified using the NVDRS provides supporting evidence for the validity of our data-driven approach.

The robustness of our approach is also supported by the stability of the clusters up to six months before death, which is replicated in held-out sets using cross-validation. Moreover, the feature importance analysis provided meaningful explanations of the clusters and highlighted the salient features predictive for each subtype. Finally, we compared the suicide subtypes to accidental deaths, showing that these subtypes are unique to suicide deaths. We recognize that death investigators may have difficulty accurately categorizing suicide deaths from accidents, especially in cases of overdose63–65. However, Maryland’s statewide medical examiner system is among the most conservative in the country66, categorizing equivocal cases as ‘undetermined manner’ and assuring that the cases categorized as suicide and accident in our study were done so with high specificity.

Despite the strengths of this study, several limitations should be noted. Our findings may not generalize to populations outside of Maryland. Additionally, while health administrative data includes hospital discharges statewide for all decedents, relying on a single-source EHR dataset from JHMI may lead to incomplete capture of certain variables. Health records also often lack detailed information on life events which could reflect circumstances leading up to death. This includes SDOH, which are known to be inconsistently documented in structured EHR fields, limiting our ability to fully capture social risk factors. The timeliness of our data presents another limitation, as suicide subtypes could shift, particularly in the context of the ongoing opioid epidemic where many overdose deaths are classified as undetermined due to difficulties in establishing intent. These limitations hinder the ability to fully understand the different factors contributing to suicide.

Our study also has methodological limitations. Although we excluded encounters occurring on the date of death to avoid artificially inflating healthcare utilization related to fatal events, earlier care associated with the suicide attempts may still be captured and could skew utilization metrics for some decedents. In addition, our use of healthcare encounter quartiles may encode information about the overall cohort distribution. While we mitigated this during model evaluation by calculating quantiles within each training fold during cross-validation, the final clustering model was trained on the full cohort using full-distribution quantiles. Although this design choice is common in unsupervised learning and enhances interpretability by reducing skew, it may introduce cohort-level bias, particularly when applied to external populations in the future.

Future research should incorporate additional data sources, including insurance claims and records from other service sectors such as schools, higher education, the justice system, and state administrative databases on job loss and divorce. Additionally, applying natural language processing to clinical notes and conducting psychological autopsies can further refine these profiles, capturing a comprehensive spectrum of decedent circumstances, including emotional insights such as hopelessness and social isolation. We also plan to assess the value of these profiles in prospectively predicting suicide within the EHR and for clinically meaningful subpopulations. Lastly, we aim to use temporal clustering techniques, which can be particularly effective in understanding the progression and dynamics of impactful life events leading up to suicide.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study introduced a data-driven approach that identified four distinct suicide profiles, three of which closely aligned with typologies previously proposed in the literature. This reinforces the reliability of our profiling methodology and indicates the broader relevance of our findings. These profiles contribute foundational information to conceptual models of suicide, as well as to efforts to expand the reach of suicide prevention approaches, emphasizing the diversity among suicide decedents. Additionally, identifying these clinical subgroups may improve precision in future predictive modeling tasks when applied prospectively. Future research should focus on prospective validation of these profiles to evaluate whether they are associated with different levels of suicide risk among living individuals, which would further establish their utility for clinical decision support and prevention efforts.

caption.p: Outline of the clustering pipeline to subtype suicide decedents. The clustering process included 81 variables. During the 5-fold stratified CV, the data was split into 80% training (n = 678 cases) and 20% testing (n = 170 cases) for each fold. Stratification was conducted on age, sex, and race to maintain representative distributions across folds. CV cross-validation, DEC deep embedded clustering, EHR electronic health records, GLRM generalized low-rank model, PS prediction strength, SHAP SHapley Additive exPlanations.

Prediction Strength for the different clustering methodologies. Prediction Strength for each clustering approach for values of k between 2 and 10. The optimal number of clusters is determined as the largest for which the PS exceeds 0.8. The optimal k is 4 clusters using DEC highlighted in the figure. AE autoencoder, DEC deep embedded clustering, GLRM generalized low-rank model.
Key defining features of the suicide profiles.
Sankey diagram for the suicide subtypes at different time points.

Comparison of Suicide and Accidental Death Clusters (A). Visualization of Suicide and Accidental Death Clusters. The UMAP visualization represents high-dimensional data in a three-dimensional space where proximity between points indicates similarity. The three axes (x, y, z) represent the dimensions of the reduced embedding space that best preserves the structure of the input data. The input data for UMAP plot were the encoded features from DEC. Note that while points within each death type (suicide or accidental) can be meaningfully compared based on their proximity, direct comparison between death types should consider that they were embedded through separate DEC models. (B). Gower distances between Suicide and Accidental Death Clusters. The heatmap shows normalized distances between clusters on a scale from 0 (identical) to 1 (maximally different). UMAP uniform manifold approximation and projection for dimension reduction.

*ED evaluation reflects the percentage of individuals who had at least one ED evaluation during the study period. ED visits refer to the median count of ED encounters per patient.
**All variables in the table were included in the clustering except for race, sex, and rurality. Table S2 contains the rest of the variables included in constructing the profiles.

notes.title: Author contributions
notes.p: A.B. drafted the original manuscript and conducted the data analysis. C.K. contributed to data preparation and assisted with model development. C.K. and A.Z. provided expertise on machine learning methodologies and validation approaches. P.N. and H.C.W. contributed to the interpretation of results and conceptual framework. H.K. supervised the project, guided the methodological approach, and contributed to manuscript development. All authors edited and provided feedback on all versions of the manuscript.

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: The datasets used and/or analyzed during the current study contain protected health information (PHI) and are subject to Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) regulations. As such, they cannot be publicly shared. Access to the data may be granted upon reasonable request to the corresponding author, subject to permission from participating data providers in MSDW and institutional and ethical review board approvals.

notes.title: Competing interests
notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
